poem:
Title: "Of Vetting and Healing"

In the quiet chorus of morning dew,
Traded stories of trust and thwarted craft,
Householder, heart heavy, scans the digital brew,
Seeking solace in a secure draft.
Postcode guardians, the hailed saviors,
Yet, under the wounded roof, doubts persist.
She, once fooled, now examines with cautious favors,
In the hope of a truer trusted list.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Does Checkatrade’s vetting really check out? Cowboy builders are a proliferating scourge which can drain a householder’s savings. In response, online platforms have sprung up which list “vetted” traders in response to a postcode search. But how reliable are they? In March, I reported how AF of Brighton was left with part of her roof missing after hiring a trader to repair a leak. To ensure that she was not scammed a second time, she". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
